Key Arguments: The bill is seen as discriminatory and undermines human rights for political advantage.
Mainstream media and political advertising are major sources of misinformation, yet they are not held accountable.
Social media, despite its issues, provides valuable information not available from mainstream media or the government.
There is a lack of accountability for mainstream media and political figures who spread misinformation.
The government is not trusted to oversee legislation due to perceived corruption and past failures.
The legislation is viewed as a distraction from more pressing issues, such as indigenous rights and environmental protection.
Main Themes: Distrust in government and mainstream media
Freedom of expression and human rights
Role of social media in information dissemination
Notable Quotes: Once again I see our government trying to undermine human rights for political advantage.
We have so much corruption and distrust of governments in Australia we canâ€™t trust them to oversee this legislation.

Fact checking is problematic, but voluntary codes of conduct or governmental intervention over independent media sources, social media and professional groups will be catastrophic for our so-called democracy.
